section.title: Choosing a Distribution's Storage and Download Locations
section.para: By default SystemBuilder uses the SystemBuilder build system as the default locatin for publication and remote access. See the section "Deploying Client Machines" under Part I, Chapter 2, and the DDFR for more information about the default settings. When the default settings are not appropriate, use the publish TLE in the distribution definition to direct SystemBuilder where to store the distribution and what URL to use to make it accessible to clients for download.

Essentially, you have one choice for the server location of the published system distribution, the SystemBuilderbuild system. However, you can choose different directories on that machine. If the /var directory is on a separate logical drive, increasing the drive capacity is easier.

For the network-accessible location of the system distribution for download, you have two choices: somewhere on the SystemBuilder build system or on another server. Choosing that location depends upon several factors: your network security topography, the location of your client systems, the types and number of distributions, the number of users accessing the distribution and the number of types of OSes used in the distributions.

SystemBuilder can accommodate a number of scenarios for storage and download. Critical considerations include whether you have a single LAN versus a separate DMZ, a download machine with multiple active interfaces, multiple active ports or secure login requirements. SystemBuilder handles all of these through the distribution definition file, e.g. samber-server.xml.

Scenario 1: Alternate publish, or storage, locations
While the publish and storage location is on the SystemBuilder build system, the default location of /var/www/html/distributions/$DISTRIBUTIONID may not meet your needs. For administrative purposes, you may wish to keep separate paths for different distributions or types of distributions or make only certain paths accessible to others for download from the SystemBuilder build system. To accomplish this, use publish/local-dir to set an alternate directory for publication. The default download URL will be the IP address of the SystemBuilder build system's first active, non-loopback network interface.
Scenario 2: Single LAN but multiple machines with one external firewall
In this scenario, you may want to have separate physical machines for build management and security administration purposes. Use publish/remote-url to specify the full URL path to the remotely accessible directory.
Scenario 3: Separate DMZ for secure remote accessibility
A separate DMZ most likely means the SystemBuilder build system is behind your external firewall for security purposes. The question is whether you want the remotely accessible download host to be there, too, or in the DMZ. To assign the distribution to a download server in the DMZ, use publish/remote-url with the full http path and machine's IP address.
Scenario 4: Multiple active interfaces
While SystemBuilder does not factor in multiple active interfaces on the SystemBuilder build machine, it does consider them for the remotely accessible server. By default it chooses the first active, non-loopback network interface. To specify another interface, enter the network card's number, e.g. "eth2," in the publish/remote-url@interface attribute.
Scenario 5: Multiple ports
To obscure and control the network communications, you can use a unique port number, e.g. 8080, in the publish/remote-url path.
Scenario 6: Secure login
SystemBuilder allows you to specify a user login name and password for download purposes using publish/remote-url. The login and password are free text.
For the remotely accessible URL for the download server, you can use either a hostname or an IP address. One key advantage to using a machine's hostname is the ease of access using single name for multiple IPs, either separately or together as a multihoned machine. Domain naming makes the download server more logically accessible as opposed to IP addresses. Finally, a hostname does not expose your IP blocks and network topology.
